content:
MICROINJECTION OF UNFERTILIZED S. PURPURATUS SEA URCHIN EGGS
GENERAL DESCRIPTION: Dejellied sea urchin eggs are fixed to protamine sulfate
coated, plastic petri dishes and injected using a continuously flowing, glass
micropipette. Eggs are fertilized in situ. Details of the protocol are given
below.
EGG Female sea urchins are injected with about 1 ml of 0.5 KCI
and shed eggs collected in a beaker filled with millipore filtered sea water
All manipulations of the eggs are carried out in Once
the eggs have settled under gravity, they are washed twice through gauze (Type
VII, Kendall Co.) to remove adhering matter, then dejellied by swirling in pH
5.0 for 4 min. The pH 5.0 is neutralized by the addition of 14
drops of 1M Tris pH 8.0 from a long-form pasteur pipette per 50 ml. The eggs
are allowed to settle and the water changed. An aliquot of the dejellied eggs
(eggs should lie close together if jelly coat has been successfully removed)
is then placed in 4 ml of in a siliconized, embryological watch-
glass.
SPERM COLLECTION: Male sea urchins are injected with about 1 ml of 0.5 
KCI. The concentrated sperm is collected using a long-form pasteur pipette
and is kept at One drop of the ejaculate is mixed with 10 ml of 
and this concentrated solution used for subsequent fertilization. The
sperm in this solution generally remain viable over the period of injection.
PROTAMINE PLATE 60 mm, "Falcon" plastic petri-dish lids are
filled and treated for 1 min with a 1% protamine sulfate solution. The timing
is critical: Too short a period and the eggs stick poorly, too long and the
eggs are unable to undergo normal elevation of the vitelline membrane on
fertilization. The hardened fertilization membrane restricts subsequent
cleavage.
Following protamine coating, dishes are washed with distilled water to
remove unadhered protamine sulfate solution, and air dried. Inefficient
washing of the dishes will result in the protamine in solution precipitating
negatively charged molecules DNA) at the needle tip. The protamine
sulfate solution may be reused several times, if kept in the refrigerator.
MICROINJECTION NEEDLE PREPARATION: Needles for microinjection are prepared
from 1.0 mm outside diameter, 0.75 mm inside diameter, borosilicate, omega dot
(Q) glass supplied by Frederick Haer and Co., Brunswick, Maine (No. 30-30-
0). It is essential that the glass is thoroughly cleaned by placing in a hot,
35% nitric acid solution for 1 hr, washing through several times with
distilled, water, and finally distilled. water filtered 0.2 mn through. a
"Gelman" filter. Cleaned glass is placed in a screw-cap test tube and dried
in an oven. Fine-tipped micro injection needles are pulled on a Brown-Flaming
micropipette puller and just prior to injection, are brushed up against a
"breaking pipette" (see below) to open the tip to a diameter of ~0.4-0.9 um.
PREPARATION GLASS PIPETTES FOR EGG TRANSFER AND FILLING INOECTION
PIPETTES: Long-form pasteur pipettes are drawn-out in a bunsen flame and
broken off at the end with a gloved-hand. Pulled pipettes are siliconized by
drawing up a solution of 1% "Prosil" and then 0.2 Lm filtered distilled H20 to
rinse. They are dried in a 110? oven.
